importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the date on which Nicolas Sarkozy began serving his five-year prison sentence, marking a historic moment in French political history as the first former EU head of state to be jailed.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline of events centers on the sentencing and immediate start of Sarkozy's prison term on this day, indicating the immediacy and significance of the legal outcome.

keyTakeAways: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy has begun a five-year jail term for criminal conspiracy related to illegal campaign financing from Muammar Gaddafi.
Sarkozy is the first former head of a European Union state to be imprisoned, making this case a landmark in EU political history.
He was found guilty of accepting millions of euros in illegal payments to fund his 2007 election campaign, which he has consistently denied.
He arrived at La Sante prison in Paris in a police car, with supporters and family members protesting outside his home.
Sarkozy will be held in solitary confinement in a nine-square-metre cell, with one daily walk and three weekly visits.
The presiding judge, Nathalie Gavarino, described the crimes as of 'exceptional gravity' and denied any possibility of release even with appeal.
His lawyers immediately filed a release appeal, which the court has two months to review.
Sarkozy expressed his innocence and stated that 'truth will prevail,' claiming to be an innocent man despite the conviction.
This marks the first time a French head of state has been imprisoned since Philippe Petain during World War II, underscoring the historical gravity of the event.
He plans to take a biography of Jesus and a copy of 'The Count of Monte Cristo' with him, referencing a narrative of an innocent man wrongfully imprisoned.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy has begun a five-year jail term at La Sante prison in Paris, becoming the first former head of a European Union state to be imprisoned. He was found guilty of criminal conspiracy for accepting millions of euros from Libyan ruler Muammar Gaddafi to fund his 2007 election campaign, a claim he has consistently denied. The presiding judge, Nathalie Gavarino, described the offenses as of 'exceptional gravity' and ruled that the conviction would stand even if an appeal is filed. Sarkozy will be held in solitary confinement with limited contact, and his lawyers have immediately filed a release appeal, which the court will review in two months. This moment marks a historic turning point in French political history, as it is the first time a former French head of state has been imprisoned since Nazi collaborator Philippe Petain. Supporters and family members protested outside his home, while Sarkozy expressed his innocence and referenced the novel 'The Count of Monte Cristo' as a symbol of justice and redemption.
title: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy starts five-year jail term
